sense.name: put, place, position
sense.commentary: Transitive. NP1 SET NP2 (PP/ADV) Includes abstract placing in a context, scenario, etc.. Includes: SET APART; SET ASHORE; SET ASIDE; SET BACK; SET DOWN; SET FORTH; SET OUT; SET TO MUSIC
sense.examples: Set your purse on the table. I'm going to set a couple of rose bushes along the back of the house. The novel is set 50 years in the future. When Franklin was a printer's apprentice, he had to set type by hand. Einstein's genius set him apart from the others. As soon as the ship docked, they were set ashore. Please set aside 3 cartons for me. He tried to set down his thoughts on paper. Let's set back the meeting an hour to give him time to prepare. She set forth her reasons, one by one. Shall I set out your clothes? That bone never set properly. He set his jaw and refused to comply. The carpenter set the nail firmly.

sense.name: go down, sink
sense.examples: At one time the sun never set on the British Empire.

sense.name: fix, determine, establish
sense.commentary: NP1 SET NP2[+abstract] (often a quantity or measurement) Includes: SET AHEAD
sense.examples: We don't have to always let her set the rules. Try your equations with X set to a negative number. The bank set interest rates on their long-term CDs at 5 percent. With that time, the runner has just set a new world record. Set the clock for daylight saving time, please.

sense.name: prepare (something) for a particular purpose
sense.examples: These packages were set to go yesterday. Your printer is all set. Will you set the table, please? How do you set up this tent? We're not set up to receive messages from offshore. I set up my schedule so that I'm home by 4:00 every day. We should set up a committee to look into that. The American Red Cross was set up in 1881 to aid victims of war and natural disasters. He set all the kitchen knives beautifully. You won't have time to set your hair before the wedding. The jeweler set rubies around the central diamond.

sense.name: (cause to) assume a condition or state
sense.examples: Don't add the pineapple until the gelatin has set at least partially. Winter has set in.

sense.name: cause to begin an activity
sense.commentary: Note: Compare to sense 7. This sense includes transitive uses only. Includes: SET ABOUT; SET FORTH; SET IN MOTION; SET OFF, SET OUT; SET UP; SET IN
sense.examples: I hope the verdict doesn't set off a riot. I set him to work on the windows. His rash words set in motion a chain of events he would intensely regret. The terrorists set off another bomb this morning. The scientists set up a shock wave. We set out to save the Shire, Sam. She set about contacting all the parents. He set into his food with gusto.

sense.name: leave
sense.commentary: Note: Compare to sense 6. This sense includes intransitive uses only. Includes: SET OFF, SET OUT
sense.examples: They set off on their morning walk. The ships set out at dawn.

sense.name: ensnare, frame, arrange through deceit
sense.examples: I was set up! That election was set up so she would win.

sense.name: (cause to) attack
sense.commentary: Includes: SET IN, SET ON, SET UPON
sense.examples: He swore he'd set the dogs on them. She was set upon by wolves. That gale could set in on us with the next high tide.

sense.name: reproduce,fructify
sense.examples: These old trees in the orchard may not set.

sense.name: dialect for SIT
sense.examples: I was jus' settin' there, when up walked the new pastor.

sense.name: multi-word expressions/MWEs
sense.commentary: Includes: SET ABLAZE; SET AFIRE; SET AFLAME; SET BACK; SET DOWN; SET FREE; SET ON FIRE; SET OFF
sense.examples: They believe vandals set fire to the school. Lightning set the forest ablaze. The truth will set you free. My daughter's wedding set me back $20,000. That white coat really sets off your dark hair.
